elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0005">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cap0005">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">2D connecting motif of complexes 1, 2 and 3, Fe⋯Fe distances were highlighted, hydrogen bonds were shown in dotted lines and hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  2D connecting motif of complexes 1, 2 and 3, Fe⋯Fe distances were highlighted, hydrogen bonds were shown in dotted lines and hydrogen atoms were omitted for clarity.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0010">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cap0010">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">(a) The connecting and packing motif of uncoordinated water molecules, perchlorate anions and uncoordinated 4,4′-bipy around iron(II) centre; (b) The motif of the “<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>-shaped holder” in the 2D grids of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr2"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 2  (a) The connecting and packing motif of uncoordinated water molecules, perchlorate anions and uncoordinated 4,4'-bipy around iron(II) centre; (b) The motif of the "S-shaped holder" in the 2D grids of 3.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="f0015">
<ce:label>Fig. 3</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cap0015">
<ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">(a) The motif of “<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>-shaped holder” connected to a 2D layer structure; (b) 3D architecture of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> connected by “<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>-shaped holder”.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr3"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 3  (a) The motif of "S-shaped holder" connected to a 2D layer structure; (b) 3D architecture of 3 connected by "S-shaped holder".

elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A new spin crossover coordination polymer (SCO-CPs) of Fe(II)-4,4'-bipyridine (4,4'-bipy) family: {Fe(4,4'-bipy)2(H2O)2}⋅(4,4'-bipy)⋅ 8(H2O)⋅2(ClO4) (3), which displays half spin transitions between 100 and 300K, has been synthesized and structurally characterized. Compound 3 featured with two-dimensional (2-D) grids connected by hydrogen bonds and π…π packing between one-dimensional (1-D) chains, the 2-D grids expand to three-dimensional (3-D) architecture supported by a "S-shaped holder" involving lattice 4-4'-bipy, water molecules and perchlorate anion. We compared 3 with the other two analogous complexes: ({Fe(4,4'-bipy) (H2O)2 (NCS)2}⋅4,4'-bipy, 1 and {Fe(4,4'-bipy)2(NCS)2}⋅mSolv, 2) through Hirshfeld surfaces analysis, which revealed that the low ligand field strength (NCS-) and lone-pair…H contacts contribute to the stabilization of HS (high-spin) state of the Fe(II) ion, while the high ligand field strength (4,4'-bipy) and strong intermolecular contacts (hydrogen bonds and π…π packing interactions) make for the LS (low-spin) state.

Graphical abstract

      

Highlights

   ● A new member of Fe(||)-4,4'-bipy family has been prepared.   ● It displays half spin transitions tuned by ligand field and intermolecular interactions.   ● We have made a detailed comparison of this new member with two other analogous complexes.

elements.clean_text:
A new member of Fe(||)-4,4'-bipy family has been prepared.

It displays half spin transitions tuned by ligand field and intermolecular interactions.

We have made a detailed comparison of this new member with two other analogous complexes.

Introduction

The design and characterization of the six-coordinated iron(II) complexes that show spin-crossover (SCO) properties remains one of the most spectacular questions in the field of magnetic materials chemistry due to their molecular bi-stability and potential applications for the development of display and memory devices, electrical and electroluminescent devices, MRI contrast agents, switchable liquid crystals, and so on . The phenomenon of transitions between high-spin (HS) and low-spin (LS) electronic states have been extensively studied during a few past decades and the results have been summarized in several reviews . The pronounced SCO properties were related to cooperative interactions (hydrogen-bonding, π…π stacking, van der Waals contacts) between the active metal ions in the crystal . An effectively approach to explore these interactions is the self-assembly of spin changing centre with suitable bridging ligands into extended one-, two-, and three -dimensional (1D, 2D, 3D) spin crossover coordination polymers (SCO-CPs). Since the first reported two series of 1D triazole-based complexes of SCO-CPs , a large number of 1D, 2D and 3D SCO-CPs based on triazoles, tetrazoles and pyridine-like bridging ligands combined with anionic bridges (cyanom etallates, dicyanamide, and polynitriles) have been reported .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Among the pyridine-like bridging ligands, the well-known bis-mono-dentate building block 4,4′-bipyridine has been widely used as an ancillary bridging ligands for the synthesis of a variety of Fe(II) SCO compounds ranging from discrete binuclear to 1D, 2D, and 3D coordination polymers . These reported 1D SCO-CPs bridged by 4,4′-bipyridine can be generically formulated as {Fe(4,4′-bipy) (<ce:italic>L</ce:italic>)<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>}·mSolv (<ce:italic>L</ce:italic>=quadridentate, <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>=1; <ce:italic>L</ce:italic>=bidentate, <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>=2 and <ce:italic>L</ce:italic>=monodentate, <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>=4) . While 2D SCO-CPs bridged by 4,4′-bipyridine usually formulated as {Fe(4,4′-bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>L</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}·mSolv (<ce:italic>L</ce:italic>=monodentate) . For example, Real  and co-workers have synthesized a 1D compound {Fe(4,4′-bipy) (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}·4,4′-bipy (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), where, the 1D chains held together by strong hydrogen bonds between the guest bi-pyridine ligands and the coordinated water molecules, which giving a 2D supramolecular array. Latter, they substituted the water molecules in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> by nitrogen-donor bidentate ligand 2,2′-bithiazoline (bt), and obtained another 1D SCO-CP {Fe(4,4′-bipy)(bt)(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} , which undergo 12% HS–LS transition. Real and co-workers further heated the complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> at about 110<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, which resulting the concerted loss of the coordinated water molecules and the coordination of the uncoordinated guest bi-pyridine molecules, and affording a 2D coordination polymer with stoichiometry {Fe(4,4′-bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>). Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> featured infinite 2D (4,4) iron-bi-pyridine grids, which act as excellent solvent host, Real. et al. have introduced nine different solvent molecules into this 2D grids, and have obtained eight HS (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">1–8</ce:inf>) host–guest complexes : <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>·2(trichloroethene) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>), <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>·2(toluene) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>), <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>·2(nitrobenzene) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>), <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>·2(ether) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>), <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>·4(acetone) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>), <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>·3(CS<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>), <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>·3(methanol) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>), <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>·2(nitromethane·methanol) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>) and a spin-crossover host–guest complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>·4(CHCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>). 
<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf> displays complete two steps SCO transitions attribute to cooperative interactions between the iron-bi-pyridine grids and CHCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> molecules. From the viewpoint of crystal engineering, we substituted the NCS<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> by water molecules, and we obtained a new 1D SCO-CP {Fe(4,4′-bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}· (4,4′-bipy)·4(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)·2(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>) (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>). The connecting motif around the iron(II) centre of complexes <ce:bold>1–3</ce:bold> were shown in <ce:float-anchor refid="f0035"></ce:float-anchor>
. The 1D chain in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> held together by strong hydrogen bonds and <ce:italic>π</ce:italic>…<ce:italic>π</ce:italic> packing interactions between the coordinated bi-pyridine ligands and water molecules into 2D grids, the 2D grids further expand to 3D architecture supported by a “S-shaped holder” composed of guest 4-4′-bipy, water and perchlorate anions. The “S-shaped holder” display efficient cooperative interactions with the 2D iron-bi-pyridine grids, which may play a key role for the half SCO transition of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. We further studied the magnetic properties of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and compared the intermolecular interactions of with <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">1–9</ce:inf> through Hirshfeld surfaces analysis .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Among the pyridine-like bridging ligands, the well-known bis-mono-dentate building block 4,4'-bipyridine has been widely used as an ancillary bridging ligands for the synthesis of a variety of Fe(II) SCO compounds ranging from discrete binuclear to 1D, 2D, and 3D coordination polymers . These reported 1D SCO-CPs bridged by 4,4'-bipyridine can be generically formulated as {Fe(4,4'-bipy) (L)n}⋅mSolv (L=quadridentate, n=1; L=bidentate, n=2 and L=monodentate, n=4) . While 2D SCO-CPs bridged by 4,4'-bipyridine usually formulated as {Fe(4,4'-bipy)2(L)2}⋅mSolv (L=monodentate) . For example, Real  and co-workers have synthesized a 1D compound {Fe(4,4'-bipy) (H2O)2(NCS)2}⋅4,4'-bipy (1), where, the 1D chains held together by strong hydrogen bonds between the guest bi-pyridine ligands and the coordinated water molecules, which giving a 2D supramolecular array. Latter, they substituted the water molecules in 1 by nitrogen-donor bidentate ligand 2,2'-bithiazoline (bt), and obtained another 1D SCO-CP {Fe(4,4'-bipy)(bt)(NCS)2} , which undergo 12% HS-LS transition. Real and co-workers further heated the complex 1 at about 110°C, which resulting the concerted loss of the coordinated water molecules and the coordination of the uncoordinated guest bi-pyridine molecules, and affording a 2D coordination polymer with stoichiometry {Fe(4,4'-bipy)2(NCS)2} (2). Compound 2 featured infinite 2D (4,4) iron-bi-pyridine grids, which act as excellent solvent host, Real. et al. have introduced nine different solvent molecules into this 2D grids, and have obtained eight HS (2 1-8) host-guest complexes : 2⋅2(trichloroethene) (2 1), 2⋅2(toluene) (2 2), 2⋅2(nitrobenzene) (2 3), 2⋅2(ether) (2 4), 2⋅4(acetone) (2 5), 2⋅3(CS2) (2 6), 2⋅3(methanol) (2 7), 2⋅2(nitromethane⋅methanol) (2 8) and a spin-crossover host-guest complex 2⋅4(CHCl3) (2 9).  2 9 displays complete two steps SCO transitions attribute to cooperative interactions between the iron-bi-pyridine grids and CHCl3 molecules. From the viewpoint of crystal engineering, we substituted the NCS- anions in 2 by water molecules, and we obtained a new 1D SCO-CP {Fe(4,4'-bipy)2(H2O)2}⋅ (4,4'-bipy)⋅4(H2O)⋅2(ClO4) (3). The connecting motif around the iron(II) centre of complexes 1-3 were shown in  . The 1D chain in 3 held together by strong hydrogen bonds and π…π packing interactions between the coordinated bi-pyridine ligands and water molecules into 2D grids, the 2D grids further expand to 3D architecture supported by a "S-shaped holder" composed of guest 4-4'-bipy, water and perchlorate anions. The "S-shaped holder" display efficient cooperative interactions with the 2D iron-bi-pyridine grids, which may play a key role for the half SCO transition of 3. We further studied the magnetic properties of 3 and compared the intermolecular interactions of with 1 and 2 1-9 through Hirshfeld surfaces analysis .

Complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> crystallizes in the monoclinic (<ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2<ce:italic>/c</ce:italic>) space group (), the basic unit of it composed of a {Fe(4,4′-bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> complex cation, two uncoordinated ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>

For the complex cation, two of the 4,4′-bipy ligands serves as a bridge ligand connecting the adjacent ions forming a linear chain and the other two are terminal ones which are mono-coordinated to the iron together with two water molecules. The coordination of Fe is thus FeN<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. The 1D linear chain structure of the complex cation along <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>-axis was shown in , the Fe–N distances for the bridged and mono-coordinated ligand are 2.29, 2.25 and 2.22<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for N1, N2 and N3, respectively (), the value of which is similar with <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, and is typical of HS Fe(II) centres. The Fe–O distance is 2.08<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, which is much shorter than that in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (2.12 (5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). All the N–Fe–N and N–Fe–O angles are in the range of 87.83–92.17°, which is also typical coordination geometry for HS Fe(II) centres. <ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf> (38.5° for Fe2, the Fe2 atom at 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K is in HS state while Fe1 is in LS state. So, we compared the geometry of around Fe2 with complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) and much smaller than <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (52.6°), and indicting that <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> may undergo SCO transition.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussions

Crystal structures

The basic structures of complexes 1-3 were shown in  , the selected bond distances and angles around the octahedron centre of complexes 1,2 9 (we choose complex 2 9 for the structural description of 2 series for the reason that it undergoes SCO transition) and 3 were tabulated in   and hydrogen bonds interactions were tabulated in  . Complex 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic (C2/c) space group (), the basic unit of it composed of a {Fe(4,4'-bipy)4(H2O)2}2+ complex cation, two uncoordinated ClO4 - anions, four uncoordinated water molecules and one uncoordinated 4,4'-bipy (). For the complex cation, two of the 4,4'-bipy ligands serves as a bridge ligand connecting the adjacent ions forming a linear chain and the other two are terminal ones which are mono-coordinated to the iron together with two water molecules. The coordination of Fe is thus FeN4O2. The 1D linear chain structure of the complex cation along a-axis was shown in , the Fe-N distances for the bridged and mono-coordinated ligand are 2.29, 2.25 and 2.22Å for N1, N2 and N3, respectively (), the value of which is similar with 1 and 2, and is typical of HS Fe(II) centres. The Fe-O distance is 2.08Å, which is much shorter than that in 1 (2.12 (5)Å). All the N-Fe-N and N-Fe-O angles are in the range of 87.83-92.17°, which is also typical coordination geometry for HS Fe(II) centres. The distortion parameter ∑  for the coordination octahedron in 3 is 40°, which is similar with 2 9 (38.5° for Fe2, the Fe2 atom at 120K is in HS state while Fe1 is in LS state. So, we compared the geometry of around Fe2 with complex 3) and much smaller than 1 (52.6°), and indicting that 3 may undergo SCO transition.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0035" view="all">It is noteworthy that the double-coordinated and single-coordinated 4,4′-bipy have different level of distortion, and the guest 4,4′-bipy are co-planar in complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, which may attribute to the strong intermolecular interactions. The angle between the pyridine rings containing the atoms N1 and N2, N3 and N4 being 28.987 (2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1)° and 7.684 (1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1)°, respectively. While the angle between adjacent 4,4′-bipys containing the atoms N1 and N2 in the 1D linear chain is 79.181 (1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5)°, which is larger than that in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The adjacent 1D linear chains in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> then connected <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> strong O–H<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>N hydrogen bonds (O–N distance of 2.743<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) interactions between the mono-coordinated 4,4′-bipy ligands and coordinated water molecules into 2D layer structure (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>
). It is noticeable that the 4,4′-bipy ligands between the adjacent chains are nearly parallel to each other by <ce:italic>π</ce:italic>…<ce:italic>π</ce:italic> interactions with plane separation of 3.674<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The Fe…Fe distances through bridged and mono-coordinated 4,4′-bipy ligands are 11.648(5) and 12.483(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. The value of which within one linear chain is a little longer than that in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, while the distance between adjacent chains is much shorter than in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> while a little longer than in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. These distances may have a close relationship with the magnetic properties, the closer distances between adjacent 1D linear chains contribute to the cooperative between active iron(II) center.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: It is noteworthy that the double-coordinated and single-coordinated 4,4'-bipy have different level of distortion, and the guest 4,4'-bipy are co-planar in complex 3, which may attribute to the strong intermolecular interactions. The angle between the pyridine rings containing the atoms N1 and N2, N3 and N4 being 28.987 (221)° and 7.684 (151)°, respectively. While the angle between adjacent 4,4'-bipys containing the atoms N1 and N2 in the 1D linear chain is 79.181 (115)°, which is larger than that in 2. The adjacent 1D linear chains in 3 then connected via strong O-H…N hydrogen bonds (O-N distance of 2.743Å) interactions between the mono-coordinated 4,4'-bipy ligands and coordinated water molecules into 2D layer structure (  ). It is noticeable that the 4,4'-bipy ligands between the adjacent chains are nearly parallel to each other by π…π interactions with plane separation of 3.674Å. The Fe…Fe distances through bridged and mono-coordinated 4,4'-bipy ligands are 11.648(5) and 12.483(5)Å, respectively. The value of which within one linear chain is a little longer than that in 1 and 2, while the distance between adjacent chains is much shorter than in 1 while a little longer than in 2. These distances may have a close relationship with the magnetic properties, the closer distances between adjacent 1D linear chains contribute to the cooperative between active iron(II) center.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0040" view="all">There are eight uncoordinated water molecules (O6, O7, O8 and O9), two perchlorate anions and one uncoordinated 4,4′-bipy (N7) in the lattice of 3 ( and ), which form an “<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>-shaped holder” bridged by O–H<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>O and O–H<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>N hydrogen bonds contacts (O–O distances are of 2.83(5), 2.73(10) and 2.81(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, O–N distance of 2.773(15)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). The “<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>-shaped holder” connects to the {Fe(4,4′-bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> complex cation through O–H<ce:sup loc="post">…</ce:sup>O hydrogen bonds interaction (O–O distances are of 2.651(11)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) between uncoordinated water O6 and coordinated O1, and <ce:italic>π</ce:italic>…<ce:italic>π</ce:italic> packing interactions (plane…plane separation 3.830<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) between coordinated and uncoordinated 4,4′-bipy (a). For the “<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>-shaped holder”, the uncoordinated water molecules and perchlorate anions are distributed symmetrically on the two ends of the uncoordinated 4,4′-bipy molecule (b). Every “<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>-shaped holder” binds to two different coordinated water molecules in adjacent 2D layers, connecting the structures into 3D architecture () with <ce:italic>π</ce:italic>…<ce:italic>π</ce:italic> packing interactions (plane…plane separation 3.830 and 3.758<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). It is the “<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>-shaped holder” that plays a key role for the stabilization of the 3D architecture and SCO transition.</ce:para>

The "S-shaped holder" connects to the {Fe(4,4'-bipy)4(H2O)2}2+ complex cation through O-H…O hydrogen bonds interaction (O-O distances are of 2.651(11)Å) between uncoordinated water O6 and coordinated O1, and π…π packing interactions (plane…plane separation 3.830Å) between coordinated and uncoordinated 4,4'-bipy (a). For the "S-shaped holder", the uncoordinated water molecules and perchlorate anions are distributed symmetrically on the two ends of the uncoordinated 4,4'-bipy molecule (b). Every "S-shaped holder" binds to two different coordinated water molecules in adjacent 2D layers, connecting the structures into 3D architecture () with π…π packing interactions (plane…plane separation 3.830 and 3.758Å). It is the "S-shaped holder" that plays a key role for the stabilization of the 3D architecture and SCO transition.

elements.clean_text:
Magnetic properties

Shown in   was the temperature dependent magnetic profiles of complexes 1  2 9  and 3. The magnetic properties of complexes 2 1-8 were all in HS state (paramagnetic), so we did not discussed here anymore. Complex 1 shown paramagnetic profile, while complex 2 9 shown complete two-steps spin transition. The temperature dependent magnetic measurements for complex 3 were performed in the temperature range 2-305K at fields of 2kOe, which shows quite another magnetic property with 1 and 2 9 due to the substitute of NCS- anions and water molecules with 4,4'-bipy ligands. The χ M T value of 3 at room temperature is 3.02cm3 Kmol-1, corresponds to the spin-only value of iron(II) at HS spin state. This value remains almost constant when cooling to around 250K and then diminishes gradually to reach a value ca. 1.13cm3 Kmol-1 at about 100K, a value which is nearly half to the value at room temperature, indicating a half HS-LS transition has occurred. Between 100 and 25K, the χ M T values remains almost constant at 1.04cm3 Kmol-1, and finally, it diminishes rapidly down to 0.15cm3 Kmol-1 at 2K. The second χ M T drop can be ascribed to zero-field splitting arising from the strongly distorted coordination sphere of the remaining HS iron(II) ions . The HS and LS states of 3 are nearly degenerated due to the strong ligand field of 4,4'-bipy and the formation of very effective hydrogen bonds between the uncoordinated 4,4'-bipy ligand and the coordinated water molecules.

<ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Compared complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> with complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>, we may get to the conclusion that the ligand field strength and the hydrogen bonds interactions between guest molecules and Fe(II)-4,4′-bipy skeleton play a key role for the occurrence of SCO. When the coordinated ligands NCS<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> and water molecules (which shown lower ligand field strength) in complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were all substituted (complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>) or partly substituted (complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) by 4,4′-bipy ligands (which shows higher ligand field strength), the paramagnetic characteristic then can be changed to be SCO transition. While for the complexes <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> series (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">1–9</ce:inf>), complexes <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">1–8</ce:inf> were all display paramagnetic behaviour despite the higher ligand field 4,4′-bipy ligands, but when the Fe(II)-4,4′-bipy skeleton of complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was surrounded by strong hydrogen bonding contacts involving guest molecules (CHCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>), then it display complete two-steps SCO transition. This phenomenon further confirmed the significant importance of intermolecular interactions on the occurrence of SCO transition. As have been shown in , there are only two hydrogen bonding contacts in complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, while there have five and four different hydrogen bonding contacts involving Fe(II)-4,4′-bipy skeleton in complexes <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, respectively.</ce:para>

When the coordinated ligands NCS- and water molecules (which shown lower ligand field strength) in complex 1 were all substituted (complex 2 9) or partly substituted (complex 3) by 4,4'-bipy ligands (which shows higher ligand field strength), the paramagnetic characteristic then can be changed to be SCO transition. While for the complexes 2 series (2 1-9), complexes 2 1-8 were all display paramagnetic behaviour despite the higher ligand field 4,4'-bipy ligands, but when the Fe(II)-4,4'-bipy skeleton of complex 2 was surrounded by strong hydrogen bonding contacts involving guest molecules (CHCl3), then it display complete two-steps SCO transition. This phenomenon further confirmed the significant importance of intermolecular interactions on the occurrence of SCO transition. As have been shown in , there are only two hydrogen bonding contacts in complex 1, while there have five and four different hydrogen bonding contacts involving Fe(II)-4,4'-bipy skeleton in complexes 2 9 and 3, respectively.

elements.clean_text:
Hirshfeld surface

Hirshfeld surface serves as a powerful tool for identification intermolecular interactions . The 3D d  norm  values are mapped onto the Hirshfeld surface by using a red-blue-white colour scheme: red regions represent closer contacts and negative d  norm  value; blue regions represent longer contacts and positive d  norm  value; and white regions represent the distance of contacts is exactly the vdW separation and with a d  norm  value of zero. The 3D d  norm  surface can resolved into 2D fingerprint plots, which analyses all of the intermolecular contacts at the same time and give a quantitatively summarizing the nature and type of intermolecular contacts experienced by the molecules in the crystal.

) to the total Hirshfeld surfaces of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, respectively. The lone-pair…H contacts contribute to the stabilization of HS state thus hinder the SCO transition, <ce:sup loc="post">12c</ce:sup> which in accordance with the magnetic measurements. The same situation was found in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
<ce:inf loc="post">1–8</ce:inf>, where, the S–H and C–H contacts comprise most to the total Hirshfeld surfaces (). For complexes <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>

The larger <ce:italic>π</ce:italic>…<ce:italic>π</ce:italic> (C–C) contacts in complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> between coordinated and uncoordinated 4,4′-bipys also make a significant contribution to the total Hirshfeld surfaces (14.8%), these results further corroborated the significant importance of intermolecular interactions on the occurrence of SCO transition. elements.clean_text: In order to correlate intermolecular interactions with the occurrence of SCO, we performed Hirshfeld surface analysis on all the three series compounds of Fe(II)-4,4'-bipy family. Shown in   were the 3D d  norm  surface and 2D fingerprint plots of complexes 1, 2 9, 2 1 and 3 (the plots of 2 2-2 8 were shown in Supporting Information). The red points on the 3D d  norm  surface are corresponding to the significant hydrogen bonds interactions (N-H and O-H), the white point and the blue point are corresponding to the C-H, C-C and H-H interactions, respectively. The 2D fingerprint plots clearly shown that the intermolecular interactions have denser plots in complexes 2 9 and 3 were than that in complexes 1 and 2 1. For complex 1, the intermolecular interactions are dominated by lone-pair…H (S-H and C-H) and H-H contacts, which comprise 22.6, 12.9 and 26.7% ( ) to the total Hirshfeld surfaces of 1, respectively. The lone-pair…H contacts contribute to the stabilization of HS state thus hinder the SCO transition, 12c which in accordance with the magnetic measurements. The same situation was found in 2 1-8, where, the S-H and C-H contacts comprise most to the total Hirshfeld surfaces (). For complexes 2 9 and 3, the largest contributions to the total Hirshfeld surfaces are dominated by H-Cl (22.3%) and H-O (22.6%) hydrogen bonding contacts, respectively. The larger π…π (C-C) contacts in complex 3 between coordinated and uncoordinated 4,4'-bipys also make a significant contribution to the total Hirshfeld surfaces (14.8%), these results further corroborated the significant importance of intermolecular interactions on the occurrence of SCO transition. Apart for those above, the presence of S-C, S-O, N-N, and C-O interactions were observed, which were all summarized in .

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="sect0050">Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">In summary, a new member of Fe(II)-4,4′-bipyridine family: ({Fe (4,4′-bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>} ·(4,4′-bipy)·8(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)·2(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>), <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) has been synthesised and characterized. Comparisons between <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and the other two analogous complexes: ({Fe(4,4′-bipy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}·4,4′-bipy, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and {Fe(4,4′-bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (NCS)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}· <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>Solv, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) revealed that the ligand field strength as well as the contacts between guest molecules and Fe(II)-4,4′-bipyridine skeleton through O–H…O hydrogen bonds and <ce:italic>π</ce:italic>…<ce:italic>π</ce:italic> packing interaction play a key role to the spin transition. Additionally, for these Fe(II)-4,4′-bipyridine family, the lone-pair…H contact contribute to the stabilization of high-spin state of the Fe(II) ion, while the stronger intermolecular hydrogen bonding and <ce:italic>π</ce:italic>…<ce:italic>π</ce:italic> packing interactions make for the low-spin state.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, a new member of Fe(II)-4,4'-bipyridine family: ({Fe (4,4'-bipy)2 (H2O)2} ⋅(4,4'-bipy)⋅8(H2O)⋅2(ClO4), 3) has been synthesised and characterized. Comparisons between 3 and the other two analogous complexes: ({Fe(4,4'-bipy)(H2O)2 (NCS)2}⋅4,4'-bipy, 1) and {Fe(4,4'-bipy)2 (NCS)2}⋅ mSolv, 2) revealed that the ligand field strength as well as the contacts between guest molecules and Fe(II)-4,4'-bipyridine skeleton through O-H…O hydrogen bonds and π…π packing interaction play a key role to the spin transition. Additionally, for these Fe(II)-4,4'-bipyridine family, the lone-pair…H contact contribute to the stabilization of high-spin state of the Fe(II) ion, while the stronger intermolecular hydrogen bonding and π…π packing interactions make for the low-spin state.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental section

Materials and physical measurements

4,4'-dipyridine, Fe(ClO4).6(H2O), and KSCN were all commercially available from Sigma Aldrich and used as received without further purification. Elemental analyses were performed by a Vario-EL III elemental analyzer for carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen of complex 3. The thermo gravimetric analyses (TGA) for the complex 3 were performed using a Mettler-Toledo TGA-DSC STARe System at a heating rate of 10Kmin-1 in an atmosphere of dry N2 flowing at 20cm3 min-1 over a range from 50 to 500°C. Samples were placed in open aluminium oxide crucibles annealed at 1100°C. The TGA-DSC dates were analyzed by using STARe SoftWare. Infrared spectra were recorded on a SHIMADZU IR prestige-21 FTIR-8400S spectrometer in the spectral range 4000-500cm-1, with the samples in the form of potassium bromide pellets. X-ray powder diffraction of complex 3 was recorded on a D8 ADVANCE XRD (Bruker, Germany) with Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.54056Å) at 40mA and 45kV. The sample was packed into a glass holder and diffraction patterns were collected over a 2θ range of 5-50, at a scan rate of 3°min-1. Temperature-dependent magnetization (M-T) of complex 3 were measured in the temperature range from 2 to 305K using a Quantum Design vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM) in a physical property measurement system (PPMS).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sect0065">Preparations of complex 3</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0075" view="all">The preparations of complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were performed by slow evaporation technique, 35<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL methanol/water (2:1 v/v) system were used. The obtained complexes were preliminary identified by elemental analysis. Complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> was obtained from methanol/water solvent system by a 1:2 stoichiometric mixtures of 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol (362<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg) Fe(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2·</ce:inf>6(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) and 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol (312<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg) 4-4′-bipyridine. Block yellow crystals of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were obtained after evaporation the mixture solvent at room temperature within one week. Elemental analysis, complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, Calcd. (%): C, 45.34; N, 10.57; H, 4.95. Found: C, 45.68; N, 10.31; H, 4.66. IR (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>):3386, 1595, 1537, 1488, 1403, 1319, 1220, 1108, 1058, 1045, 1000, 892, 808, 728, 622, 470 ( in Supporting information section). The thermal behaviour of complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> was done on a STARe System (Mettler-Toledo), <ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>
 shows the TG profiles of it in temperature range 50–400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Up on heating, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> undergo three steps of mass loss, the first mass-loss step was in the temperature range 70–100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. which is refer to the decomposition of lattice water molecules (mass loss experimental: ca. 16.75% and calc., ca. 16.98%); the second decomposition was in temperature range of 160–210<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. with mass loss of ca.20.08%, which refer to the decomposition of ClO4<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions (calc., ca. 19.88%); the third step of mass loss was attribute to the partly decomposition of 4-4′-bipyridine molecules, in the temperature range of 270–360<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. with mass loss of ca.40.02% (calc., ca. 44.19%); the residual species was stable above 360<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. The PXRD pattern of crystalline samples of complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> was shown in .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Preparations of complex 3

The preparations of complex 3 were performed by slow evaporation technique, 35mL methanol/water (2:1 v/v) system were used. The obtained complexes were preliminary identified by elemental analysis. Complex 3 was obtained from methanol/water solvent system by a 1:2 stoichiometric mixtures of 1mmol (362mg) Fe(ClO4)2⋅6(H2O) and 2mmol (312mg) 4-4'-bipyridine. Block yellow crystals of 3 were obtained after evaporation the mixture solvent at room temperature within one week. Elemental analysis, complex 3, Calcd. (%): C, 45.34; N, 10.57; H, 4.95. Found: C, 45.68; N, 10.31; H, 4.66. IR (KBr, cm-1):3386, 1595, 1537, 1488, 1403, 1319, 1220, 1108, 1058, 1045, 1000, 892, 808, 728, 622, 470 ( in Supporting information section). The thermal behaviour of complex 3 was done on a STARe System (Mettler-Toledo),   shows the TG profiles of it in temperature range 50-400°C. Up on heating, 3 undergo three steps of mass loss, the first mass-loss step was in the temperature range 70-100°C. which is refer to the decomposition of lattice water molecules (mass loss experimental: ca. 16.75% and calc., ca. 16.98%); the second decomposition was in temperature range of 160-210°C. with mass loss of ca.20.08%, which refer to the decomposition of ClO4- anions (calc., ca. 19.88%); the third step of mass loss was attribute to the partly decomposition of 4-4'-bipyridine molecules, in the temperature range of 270-360°C. with mass loss of ca.40.02% (calc., ca. 44.19%); the residual species was stable above 360°C. The PXRD pattern of crystalline samples of complex 3 was shown in .

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="sect0070">X-ray crystallographic study</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0080" view="all">The single-crystal X-ray diffraction data of the complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> was collected at 293<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K with graphite monochromated Mo <ce:italic>K</ce:italic>α radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>=0.071073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm), equipped with a Rigaku SCX mini diffractometer . The lattice parameters were integrated using vector analysis and refined from the diffraction matrix, the absorption correction was carried out by using a Bruker SADABS program with multi-scan method. The crystallographic data, data collection, and refinement parameters for complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were given in <ce:float-anchor refid="t0020"></ce:float-anchor>
. The structures were solved by the full-matrix least-squares method on all F2 data, and the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs  were used for structure solution and refinement, respectively.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallographic study

The single-crystal X-ray diffraction data of the complex 3 was collected at 293K with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ=0.071073nm), equipped with a Rigaku SCX mini diffractometer . The lattice parameters were integrated using vector analysis and refined from the diffraction matrix, the absorption correction was carried out by using a Bruker SADABS program with multi-scan method. The crystallographic data, data collection, and refinement parameters for complex 3 were given in  . The structures were solved by the full-matrix least-squares method on all F2 data, and the SHELXS-97 and SHELXL-97 programs  were used for structure solution and refinement, respectively.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Results and discussions

Crystal structures

The basic structures of complexes 1-3 were shown in  , the selected bond distances and angles around the octahedron centre of complexes 1,2 9 (we choose complex 2 9 for the structural description of 2 series for the reason that it undergoes SCO transition) and 3 were tabulated in   and hydrogen bonds interactions were tabulated in  . Complex 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic (C2/c) space group (), the basic unit of it composed of a {Fe(4,4'-bipy)4(H2O)2}2+ complex cation, two uncoordinated ClO4 - anions, four uncoordinated water molecules and one uncoordinated 4,4'-bipy (). For the complex cation, two of the 4,4'-bipy ligands serves as a bridge ligand connecting the adjacent ions forming a linear chain and the other two are terminal ones which are mono-coordinated to the iron together with two water molecules. The coordination of Fe is thus FeN4O2. The 1D linear chain structure of the complex cation along a-axis was shown in , the Fe-N distances for the bridged and mono-coordinated ligand are 2.29, 2.25 and 2.22Å for N1, N2 and N3, respectively (), the value of which is similar with 1 and 2, and is typical of HS Fe(II) centres. The Fe-O distance is 2.08Å, which is much shorter than that in 1 (2.12 (5)Å). All the N-Fe-N and N-Fe-O angles are in the range of 87.83-92.17°, which is also typical coordination geometry for HS Fe(II) centres. The distortion parameter ∑  for the coordination octahedron in 3 is 40°, which is similar with 2 9 (38.5° for Fe2, the Fe2 atom at 120K is in HS state while Fe1 is in LS state. So, we compared the geometry of around Fe2 with complex 3) and much smaller than 1 (52.6°), and indicting that 3 may undergo SCO transition.

Magnetic properties

Shown in   was the temperature dependent magnetic profiles of complexes 1  2 9  and 3. The magnetic properties of complexes 2 1-8 were all in HS state (paramagnetic), so we did not discussed here anymore. Complex 1 shown paramagnetic profile, while complex 2 9 shown complete two-steps spin transition. The temperature dependent magnetic measurements for complex 3 were performed in the temperature range 2-305K at fields of 2kOe, which shows quite another magnetic property with 1 and 2 9 due to the substitute of NCS- anions and water molecules with 4,4'-bipy ligands. The χ M T value of 3 at room temperature is 3.02cm3 Kmol-1, corresponds to the spin-only value of iron(II) at HS spin state. This value remains almost constant when cooling to around 250K and then diminishes gradually to reach a value ca. 1.13cm3 Kmol-1 at about 100K, a value which is nearly half to the value at room temperature, indicating a half HS-LS transition has occurred. Between 100 and 25K, the χ M T values remains almost constant at 1.04cm3 Kmol-1, and finally, it diminishes rapidly down to 0.15cm3 Kmol-1 at 2K. The second χ M T drop can be ascribed to zero-field splitting arising from the strongly distorted coordination sphere of the remaining HS iron(II) ions . The HS and LS states of 3 are nearly degenerated due to the strong ligand field of 4,4'-bipy and the formation of very effective hydrogen bonds between the uncoordinated 4,4'-bipy ligand and the coordinated water molecules.
